body:
The branch is seen at https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=reef.git (although it doesn't have tag release-0.15.0-rc1), so I think it's ok to proceed with updating the master branch with new version.

@shulmanb If all release-blocking issues have been resolved, yes you can proceed to call a vote on RC1.
@tcNickolas Rigth, forgot to tag it. Will do now.

We can use that, though I'm not sure how much of Python script it will save us (maybe we could use this in `doap.rdf`). I'll file a separate JIRA to include this in `update_website.py`
Other than that, LGTM. Seeing how there are no other comments on this PR, I'll merge this.

@markusweimer Just to make sure I understand: each caching option in the enum becomes an implementaiton of interface. Makes sense over long run. An alternative is to merge this one and then create another work item. I leave it to @afchung to decide.

> each caching option in the enum becomes an implementaiton of interface.

Yes, that is the idea. It makes the memory hierarchy itself extensible. Not sure whether that is overkill, and I am not saying we should do this instead of this PR. It just occurred to me as an alternative design while doing the code review.
Got it... @afchung once you address 1-2 minor comments suggested by markus, I will merge.
@markusweimer as an example of memory extensibility, GPU memory is example of another cache we might want to extend to later on :)

@markusweimer @dkm2110 Thanks for the comments!

So, are we suggesting to merge this first? I am a bit worried that if we go with this current design it will just stick. If we don't envision supporting _a lot_ more caching levels, I think this would be okay, but otherwise I would like to re-submit a PR.

I'm also thinking of changing the `interface` `IDataMover` to an `abstract` class with a base implementation that all throw `NotImplementedException` for every method, such that it will not break backward compatibility should we decide to extend it.

What do you think?

> So, are we suggesting to merge this first?

I am fine either way. But with stuff like non-volatile memory complicating matters on the horizon, I'd be in favor to also work on the extensible API. 

Regarding the `abstract` class: I'm not in favor of these. They create maintenance issues down the line. We could always evolve the API via extension methods instead.

@markusweimer extension methods are not overrideable and do not provide strong hints for the user to override them. How would an `abstract` class that only throws `NotImplementedException` create maintenance issues down the line?
@jwang98052 done with another pass.
The JIRA discussion on this hasn't converged yet. Let's resolve what to do about the state management over there.
Should `DriverJobSubmissionDirectory` be deprecated then? If so, we should use its documentation for `JobSubmissionDirectory`, as it is much better :)
@markusweimer agreed. Created REEF-1402.
Tested on HDInsight.

@markusweimer I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Would also be great if you could provide feedback as to why we shouldn't use `abstract` classes in this simple case to improve extensibility. Thanks!
I have created REEF-1404 for task state maintenance and preservation for IMRU Task at Evaluator side.
@afchung @markusweimer I have addressed the review comments and left some questions to clarify.
Abstract classes create a fragile base class problem. Pure abstract classes by definition don't, though.
@afchung @markusweimer  So, is it ready to merge? I will do it then.

LGTM. The only thing is public GetPartitionHandle() returns IEnumerable<T>. @dkm2110 do you have any comment on it? I may missed it in above discussions. I remember I returned IEnumerable<T> at the first time but changed it to return T as requested by you. Was there any special reason? 
To me return IEnumerable<T> is OK. But the follow up Jira must ensure the test cases are updated as all the test cases pass IEnumerable<int> or IEnumerable<byte>. Without the change, it will end up IEnumerable<IEnumerable<T>>.
@jwang98052 Done with another round of review.
I've done a pass.
Good catch, @jwang98052! What is the reason to revert to `IEnumarable` here?
LGTM. Will merge.

I am a bit confused about the test. It tests that failing Evaluators are noticed and that new Evaluators can be requested, right? If so, it seems to be in the wrong package, as this has nothing to do with YARN.
LGTM
@afchung Thanks for the review! I have addressed your review comments. Please look at it again. Thanks!

@jwang98052 @markusweimer At that point my thinking was that Generic type T itself can be IEnumerable<T> if needed. I had raised this in the earlier PR related to this JIRA to @afchung . I am pasting his response below from earlier PR:

"We need this because we would ideally like to be able to map a Stream to an object with the new ISerializer interface. The ISerializer does not have a natural way to map multiple files to a single T. This allows more flexibility - the user can always merge streams and return a single T if that is what they would like in their implementations."
@tcNickolas I have addressed your review comments. Thanks!

@jwang98052 I have left some comments. Main concerns are timeouts introduced in *Host tasks and tests since they actually do not check the *Host tasks. Can't we take the current IMRU BroadcastAndReudce or MapperCount test and modify them for this purpose or even something simpler?

@dkm2110 Regression testing for IMRU functional tests passed. 
To reach the code path in testing, we need to send close event to the host tasks, that requires IMRU driver change, but that is REEF source code and we are not suppose to change it for test purpose. Can we only change the test code with IMRU driver and IMRUClient unchanged to achieve the test purpose,? Any suggestion?

@jwang98052  Why do you need IMRU driver to check UpdateTaskHost and MapTaskHost? They are used in IMRU but do not need IMRU driver for testing. You can take Group Communication functional tests and there as master and slave tasks inject these *Host tasks. You simply need to define Map and Update functions needed by *Host tasks. Map function can be Identity and Update function can simply transmit an integer. Basically Master and Slave tasks in GC become Update and Map functions. Then modify the driver so that when you have all the RunningTasks, you send close message to one of the tasks. In one test send it to MapTaskHost and in other to UpdateTaskHost.

Most of the code already exists and just needs to be massaged a little.
Looks good with respect to my comments.
I will test and merge it.
@dkm2110 I have addressed your review comments. Thanks!

This is interesting. We have had two different interpretations of what the type `T` of a partition is:
- It is a pointer to the real data. This is what we've done so far. `T` could be `IEnumarable<T2>` in that case.
- It is the record type. This seems to be the mode we are going after now.

Of course, algos mostly care about their record type. However, I think exposing it like this here is problematic. If we expose it here, we end up prescribing many potentially differentiating approaches to this: How to manage memory? How to serialize data? Is it a stream or an `IEnumerable`? 

Hence, I'd favor a layered design as we had so far. Or does that close the door on other optimizations?
I have done a pass.
@markusweimer I agree with the package issue. I can move it if you think it's fine to include in this PR.

I see, thanks for the explanation. I think either way is fine and won't necessarily preclude any optimizations, as an `IEnumerable<T>` can easily consist only of a single object and a `T` can also be an `IEnumerable` of some type of object. `T` here in this PR doesn't necessarily need to be a record type, it can also be a some pointer to a record type where you pass it through another transformation function to obtain the actual record type. @dkm2110 what was the original intention of the design?

For the `ISerializer` interface provided in this PR, one can implement a `Stream` that multiplexes between multiple `Stream` s. Either way, the muxing logic has to be implemented by the user. Personally I find it a bit unnatural for a Serializer to deserialize a collection of `Stream` s to a single object.

@markusweimer @dkm2110 @jwang98052 On another note, I've been working on another more extensible `DataCache<T>` (which uses some Reflection techniques that I don't really like...), but we'll still need to answer the question of what `T` is intended to be first.

I'll provide an update with a link to a branch with the new design in the JIRA once I am done. Thanks!
@markusweimer I've addressed your comments, please have another look. Thanks!

@afchung So as a ML algorithm developer, I  do not access data like IEnumerable<Record> . There will always be some Data class that will encapsulate this Enumerable and will have other functions  - NumberOfPoints, DataTimesVector etc. are some examples. So in my mind when I do GetPartitionHandle() in my algorithms for example mapper in IMRU, I will get this Data class than enumerable only. And as you said, nothing stops us from T being IEnumerable<Record> anyways.
Regarding ISerializer, as a user I do not care if data is in multiple streams or files. What I see at the end is a single data class that will read from these multiple streams using whatever logic.

Also another interesting case that I encountered just now is to extend cache layer API to any variable and not necessarily input only. For example, consider simple K-Means. For big data if number of centers and dimensionality both are big, I would like to store the centers as chunks on disk and then when needed load and use them chunk by chunk.

> I agree with the package issue. I can move it if you think it's fine to include in this PR.

I'm OK with that. This is test code, so we are not beholden to our choices in the way we are for `public` interfaces.

@markusweimer @dkm2110 I have addressed your review comments. Please look at it again. Thanks! 

I have spent almost a day to create a test driver for IMRU tasks. It is not simply to replace task class name in task configuration and add map.update function config with existing BroadCastReduce test driver, it involves too many configurations including group communication config, dataset/IInputPartition config, all the codec config, group communication client config, I was almost rewrite another IMRU driver but still end up wrong configurations. I feel we might just use IMRU driver and modify it for testing, but I am not sure if we should duplicate the prod code in testing, especially we are rewriting it now. For now, I don't think we should spend so much time to rewrite some thing for this type of testing. It should be covered by E2E testing.
I'll test this.
The tests pass for me, but fail on AppVeyor. @afchung can you check the appveyor logs?
I'll test and merge this.
@afchung Is this ready for another review?
I've done a pass.
I've done a pass.

@markusweimer I have addressed your review comments. Please look at it again. 
For IMRUTask testing, I have come out a solution and tests cases. As it involves several classes, I would like to have a separate PR for it. REEF-1408 is created to track it.
@markusweimer I have addressed your review comments. Please have a look. Thanks.
@markusweimer yes, please have another look. Thanks!

@markusweimer @dkm2110 @jwang98052 thanks the review and for all the helpful comments. Let me close this PR first such that it doesn't accidentally get merged. We should converge on design on the JIRA item first. I'll post up a link to my new design shortly. Thanks!
@afchung Thanks...However, this whole process has been very helpful since this caching aspect is extremely important.
@afchung @dkm2110 @markusweimer Do you still have any comments for this PR?

@jwang98052 except test comments LGTM. @markusweimer @afchung please do not merge this one right away. @jwang98052  once everybody sign off please leave a message and I will test with 1000 evaluators on cluster since the changes here include the ones in current IMRUDriver too.

@dkm2110 it would be nice if you can do a regression testing. Thanks!

I already have REEF-1408 ready in my private branch to test IMRUTasks and all test cases have passed. I didn't send it for review because it has dependency on this PR. But if you would like to review it now, I can also send it for CR. It cannot be merged until this PR is merged.
@jwang98052  I will do it once everybody signs off. I do not want to do it again and again.
I'll do another pass.
@markusweimer detected another possible deadlock and fixed it, please have another look. Thanks!
@markusweimer AppVeyor is failing on the known failing test.

Looks good overall to me as well, but I also agree with @dkm2110 on the test comment. I think we should be using a real IMRU Task or find a way to mock it out instead of using an ad-hoc testing class.
Tested REEF HA on HDInsight. Thanks!

@afchung I have addressed your comments. Please look at it again. Thanks! 

The tests for IMRU tasks is addressed in REEF-1408, pending for REEF-1403 deadlock solution and this REEF-1392 to check in.  Those tests have been passed.

Could you review this when you have some time?

Thank you so much, @johnyangk !
You're fast. :-)
This LGTM. Will test & merge.
LGTM, will merge
I'll test this.

> AppVeyor is failing on the known failing test.

Dang! I was hoping the fix for this would also fix that one.
@markusweimer are we able to get the logs for that test failure? I was never able to reproduce it locally.

I now have a failure in `Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.Failure.TestEvaluatorWithActiveContextImmediatePoison.TestPoisonedActiveContextHandlerImmediate`. I will locate the logs and make them available.
@markusweimer Addressed your comment. Thanks!
Logs are [here](https://onedrive.live.com/redir?resid=5801726772BFC3DA!287230&authkey=!AGRkh8VgXznoaHQ&ithint=file%2czip)

@markusweimer I've taken a brief look at the test, and I believe that the test is failing on a race condition. The test triggers an `Alarm` on `ContextStart` which fails the Evaluator and exits the Evaluator process. On the exit of the Evaluator process, the local ResourceManager detects that the process has exited first and tells the Driver that the Evaluator has failed before the first Context Heartbeat is triggered, so the Driver does not know about the Evaluator's failed context, which our test asserts to exist, causing the test failure. We should fix the test such that we check for a failed context only after the `ActiveContextHandler` has been triggered which will need to rely on Driver-Evaluator messaging.
I'm not particularly fond of that fix though, since it adds additional complexity into what is supposed to be a fairly simple test.
@afchung I have addressed your comments. Could you please have another look? Thanks!
@jwang98052 your change was not pushed.
@afchung Thanks for the reminder. I thought I have pushed in Saturday.
@markusweimer @dkm2110 Do you still have any comments? Thanks!
OK. So this change can go in. Will merge.

> The test triggers an Alarm on ContextStart which fails the Evaluator and exits the Evaluator process.

I think that is the bug. The Evaluator should first send the error to the Driver and then exit.
Mostly looks good to me, but I'm still a bit iffy about not using a real IMRU Task.
@jwang98052  LGTM.
@markusweimer Do you still have any comments before the merge?

I agree with @afchung and @dkm2110 on the testing. We need to have good testing for this functionality. However, building a test framework for IMRU will probably make this change much bigger. Hence, I think it might be better to do as a separate code review as part of REEF-1408.
I've done another pass leaving one comment.
